author: verguts
title: Build and play
review:
A nice set with some new figures.

 

Pros

  • new action figures
  • fits perfect with other ewok-sets
  • multiple nice action play features (catapult,...)
  • Solid building, parts will not come off too easy

  •  

  • Cons

  • little building excitement
  • Scout-Trooper speeder different from previous speeders

 

A nice set wich form a good supplement for other Ewok-sets.

Not much to say about.

author: Shistavanen_brick
title: Furry ones to save the universe.
review:
I picked this up last week (late May) at Toys R' Us and the box was cheaper here than other places I looked. Don't know if that is "normal" but I didn't complain. The box itself was nicely designed and looked promising. After unboxing it I couldn't agree more! It is very promising.

The minifigures.
LEGO has really done a nice job with the ewoks included in this set. The paint-job on Logray and Tokkat are just stunning. Very accurate features down to the little bag on Logray's right side. Tokkat looks like a black version of Paploo (Battle of Endor). If LEGO decides to make an ewok village these two would fit right in, and complete such a set. They come with two weapons, a spear and a bow. It would be nice to have had some traditional ewokese weapon perhaps but those included do just fine. 

Also, there is a biker scout included. It is also very detailed and looks good. If you compare this set to the 2002 release with the same name you perhaps remember that you also got a stormtrooper with it too. Not in this set. To compensate they turned the trooper into a big tree instead! I'd wish there was another imperial soldier with this set though, even if the three minifigures are great nonetheless.

The tree.
This is really no ordinary tree, as it apparently can be found on Endor there is no mistake that it has some ewokese touches! It has no less than 4 traps/weapons attached to it apart from a hollow tree feature (open up and place an ewok inside). It's a really dangerous tree if you are on the wrong side of the fight. Not only that, but the ewoks have weapons too, as said above. 

- Catapult. There's a small catapult on the treetop that fires very well.
- Logs. One of the traps release two logs on bypassers below.
- Long branch knock-out. There's a long branch running through the entire tree in perfect   head level.
- Flick fire missile. Open up the tree and fire at the speeder bike...or whatever you want     to hit. 

It is a really nice build and there are plenty of green tree pieces included to create a cool treetop. I reckon one should by at least two of this set to make a cool diorama. As a display set it works well with visiting Star Wars fans.

Pros:
  • Very cool ewoks!
  • Tree has a lot of functions.
  • Nice build and looks great when completed.

Cons:
  • One more Imperial, pleeeeease...
  • ...hmm... can't think of anything special.

author: captain_radda_radda
title: A Major Disappointment
review:
To start off I am not a fan of Ewoks. The only reason I bought this set was for the speeder. That being said, I already had a poor, yet optimistic attidude when buying this set.

 

The Minifigs

The minifigs are superb. They should definitely be the driving factor when considering to buy this set, as each is unique and rather rare. (The Endor Bunker is harder to find now)

 

The Set

The tree fort is, well...a hot mess. Branches are placed randomly and the area wear the Ewoks attack is cramped. The flick missle is useless and the head-rammer-log-thing in the center is ineffective and utterly unusable. The log drop feature works and is really the only feature that makes sense and is fun to play around with. The minicatapault is really nothing special, but it works and actually fits in to the set. The Speeder is great and its always nice to have an extra Scout. The changes in the speeder are actually rather useful, since the prongs in the front are now held together and aren't easily broken off.

 

Overall

The finished product is really just a jumbled up mess of brown bricks. It starts to look like a tree from the ground up, but eventually evolves into some kind of flatened sand surface that somehow has branches on it. Also, it is very, very small. However, I must say that it looks somewhat more presentable when combined with the Endor Battle Bunker.

 

Get it if:

You really like Ewoks

You need a Scout/Speeder

You like trees

You're an Original Trilogy completionist (like myself)

The set is on sale. (It is actually! $20 at Target (U.S.) from 8/13/11 - 8/20/11)

author: Orthobotrex
title: Low tech meets high tech
review:
This is a relatively small OT set. It features three minifigs, a speeder bike and a tree base.

 

The Package

All the parts come in polybags, though the manual is still laid bare inside, so you might find folds and bends. The box is relatively large to what you'll assemble from the contents, in my opinion. The ewok heads are packed separately inside the polybags.

 

The Minifigs

The new ewok characters are rendered in great detail, especially Logray's head ornaments. They come with their individual weapons. And they are cute, as usual. The scout trooper has the usual black head with the helmet and the usual torso prints.

 

The Build

Speeder Bike

This speeder bike is many ways similar to the the one in the snow trooper battle pack though it is quite longer. The rear is extended a bit, which in my opinion is unnecessary, giving it a bare area.
The main body has the same features as the newer speeders. The area over the control levers may be quite a disappointment as the build gives it only a very narrow space to tilt sideways. The plate with the axle jams against the loudhailer when turning it to the right. The rest of the build is smooth sailing. It has a very good swoosh factor as the other
speeders in its league.

The Ewok Base

This part of the build is quite fun but I guess is generally aimed at children. Constructing the  compartments gives a good insight into how to add volume in a relatively small area.

It is also rigged with a lot of familiar and well placed booby traps and other weapons. You have a sliding wood plank to stop any trooper caught unaware. There is also a hatch where Tokkat  can appear out of nowhere and hit with his arrow. Logray mans the upper portion where you have the falling logs and the rotating catapult. If there were any additional parts for tree building, one could easily build a very nice tree house. The ladder gives it a sense of accessibility.

And, of course, there is the flick-fire missile ...why must it be there? why? This is an excess on its own, in my opinion.

Cons

The placement and (ultimately) the sparsity of the foliage would add more to the feeling of a good tree base with adequate cover and would somehow make up for the use of the BURP. Seriously, I think a few more stems and leaves won't hurt (maybe only our pockets).

As I don't like the somewhat limited excursion of the speeder's sideways motion at the controls, I exchanged the places of the 1x1 round plates at a lower location and the 1x2 plate with a vertical bar in a similar fashion as the snowspeeders, giving it a sense of better maneuverability without taking out or adding parts.

 

Extra parts

You get an extra droid arm, two technic pins, a 1x1 round plate, and a  1x2 plate, among others.

Overall, it is a relatively fun build (though somewhat juvenile) and the minifigs are a great addition to anyone's collection.

author: The_Reviewer
title: Smaller than I thought
review:
I got this set a Target at the usual price and so far there two flaws in this set;The size and the price.

Box/Instructions

The box is just the usual Star wars box and instructions(I don;t now if it's just me,but the instructions are hard to read since there are a lot of brown pieces)

Parts

Mainly brown pieces and tree leafs.

Minifigures

The minifigs are pretty good since you get a brand new logray and tokkat minifigs with new details and face features and a rare scout trooper.

The build

Nothing special;not at all challenging

The completed model

Really small,in fact smaller than youd think for a set thats $25,but at least it comes with a speeder bike that is somewhat similar to the 2009 ones.(I dislike the way how they keep changing it)

Summary

This is not a bad set for the minifigs,but find it on sale,and don't buy it if you don't like Star wars. -Thanks for Reading

author: ewok123
title: An awesome comeback
review:
I've always been a big fan of ewok sets and I'm glad they made this set since they hardly make ewok sets. 

Pros:

great minifigs

great amount of traps(for such a small set)

nice design

Cons:

hard to put scout on speeder

difficult to build


Overall

This is really an impressive set if you like or even don't like star wars.

author: roborovskilego
title: Is that really a tree?
review:
Ewok...ATTACK!  That was not just a tree.  It was an ewok hideout!  Check out all these awesome features that belong to the ewok attack!

BUILDING EXPERIENCE: 4 BRICKS - I rated this building experience a four because it was sort of short.  Building too fast means less enjoyment.  I think building is one of the best parts of having a Lego set.  I still gave it a four, though, because it was fun to build all the weapons!  I also loved building the secret door which one of the ewoks can hide in at a time.  I also loved the flick missile, the catapult, and the logs.  

PARTS: 5 BRICKS - I rated parts five bricks because this set has all types of cool stuff!  I especially loved the catapult piece because its very unique.  You don't find those in every set!  I also loved the door piece.  Those are a little more common than the catapult pieces, but they are fairly uncommon as well.  Logray's bow is also a nice piece.  A few more pieces I liked were the tree's leaves and Tokkat's spear.

PLAYABILITY: 5 BRICKS - Perhaps the best part of this set is the playability.  The catapult launches really far if you don't point it at yourself like I did once.  Your sure to find out when you launch it.  The log that goes through the middle does best when you flick it on one end.  You can also release the two logs on the top by pulling the little handle back.  Most people know you have to flick the missile.  Just open the hideout door located under the ladder and flick that missile.  Also you can fit one ewok in the hideout door.  This set's playability is AWESOME! 

OVERALL RATING: 4 BRICKS - The reason why I gave this four stars was because I think the building experience was more of a low four stars.  I have back up for anything else in the information above.  I hope you enjoyed the review!

ROBOROVSKILEGO

author: Huge_Nerd
title: Return of Castle Forestmen--er, Ewoks!
review:
I've been wanting this set for some time and I finally got it with a coupon at TRU. I, personally, was not let down.

Let me say, right off the bat, as the previous reviewer mentioned, this set is very reminiscent of the Castle Forestmen sets of the 80s--from the minifig weapons, to the parts used in building the tree, the build itself, the way the tree opens up, etc. For me, though, that was a big plus. I felt very nostalgic building it.

The tree-fort is very fun. The little catapult works nice as does the log-dropping device. I personally like the "clothesline" branch trap the best--it's fun to hang the scout trooper bent over it as his bike goes off without him. The flickfire is a bit tacked on, but I always enjoy flickfire--plus it serves as a weapon rack for the bow so Tokkat can fit inside the tree.

The speeder bike is pretty standard, but they are always fun to have.

The Ewok minifigs are incredibly detailed. Logray was always a favorite as a kid so I was excited to get a Lego version of him. His churi-bird skull, pouch, and spear--as well as his extra height--all fit the character perfectly. I was less familiar with Tokkat, but his black and green color scheme make him perfect for hiding in the shadows of the tree. The scout trooper was a little disappointing. With no back or helmet printing, he seems very plain compared to standard Stormtroopers. That being said, he's the perfect foil for the Ewoks to beat up on.

The MSRP price is pretty fair given all the playability, but as always, discounts are better!

author: AETerry
title: Ewok Attack Review
review:
I find myself disappointed with this set. Starting off when I saw it on the shelf, I got all excited for Ewoks! A new speeder bike design! Return of the Jedi and a set depicting some of my favorite scenes in the Original Trilogy. You've got Logray as a minifigure and another ewok, Tokkat. The box art made it really look exciting.

One of the problems I have with the set, is after you've got it all put together, it's smaller then expected and thus giving a feeling that this is about $5 too much. Unless you're counting the Star Wars label, $3 for minifigures and about $16 for the piece count. Then that might all work out.

I will start with the speeder bike. This was fairly quick and easy with a new design/build for the speeder bike that makes the other two models I've got, look primitive. The body for the tri-wheeler motorcycles is used as the base for the speeder bike and the end result is just far better then older models. There are new element pieces this time around since the old bikes of 10 years ago. Meaning there's just better ways to build and create the speeder that couldn't be done before and this one I'd love to see a smaller set of just the speeder bike made available so more of this newer model can be made.

It's the tree build where I am marking points down at for this set. You really do start off with a great base for the tree and pieces for making it. The problems that I get from this set are the little flick missile weapon in the trunk of the tree. You're supposed to be able to open the  trunk on it's hinges to get to this missile.

Now I can see where LEGO might intend the smaller hands of a child to be able to reach this weapon. Being a woman and having small hands myself; having a fairly delicate touch, I'm not a fumble fingers and I'm able to often times get into the small places to do any delicate work and handling of LEGO pieces - I do not -see- how a child is suppose to get their fingers inside the trunk and be able to use the flick weapon. It's impossible to get hands or even fingers in there to fire it.

You get to the top of the tree build and it just becomes flat and there's hardly any more tree build coming out. Yeah. The small tiny catapult kind of works, but it's also placed on the set blocking the ladder up. And the log trap kind of works too, but isn't all that exciting. Plus there's a piece that slides on the trunk that I don't see what that's used for or it's purpose.

There was just huge amount of potential with this set for part of the forest battle between the Ewoks and Empire and it fails, falling flat. I love it for Logray, Tokkat and being able to have more ewoks. And I love the new speeder bike model.

Find the set on sale at $20 or less. Obviously if you're a fan of Ewoks, Speeder Bikes, any of the Return of the Jedi Endor sets, this set is a must for the collection.

author: bod3
title: A great LEGO set (BUT ONLY IF YOU DON'T PAY Â£26 FOR IT!)
review:
I recived this set for Christmas, and I was quite impressed with it, however I wouldn't pay £26 for it as  this is a complete rip-off! My parents payed £16 for it, (on Amazon) which is a decent price, and £16 should really be the RRP. It comes with 3 mini figs (Tokkat, Logray and a scout trooper) the main part of the set is a tree containing lots of nice features, such as a catapult and a tree branch which can be pushed through the tree to knock the scout trooper of the speeder bike. The speeder bike itself is nothing special and the tree is a bit unrealistic but they work well together and i think LEGO haven't done a bad job with this set.

 

  • Pros
  •  
  • Lots of playability
  • Excellent features
  • Really good detail
  • Awesome mini-figs
  • Rare peices
  •  
  •  
  • Cons

Stupid RRP

Unrealistic tree

 

To conclude, I think that this set is a must have for all Lego Starwars fans particulary if you love Starwars episode VI, but please do not pay £26 for it. I would recomend this set to the younger people because of the vast amount of playability this set offers, and older people because it is a nice model to look at.

author: Holton
title: It's a (very playable) tree.
review:
I was not originally going to buy this model but a budget restriction (aka 'my wife') meant that it was either this or the Sith Nightspeeder (7957).  As a fan of the original trilogy first-and-foremost it was not really a choice.  In addition, I have been wanting to get my hands on a scout trooper to add to my Imperial army for some time now.

Box/Instructions

The box was, as ever, attractive and gives accurate demonstrations of all the trap gimmicks on the back.  Again, it has the clone trooper header though which just looks out of place on a Classic Star Wars themed set.

Instructions were clear for the most part.  It is split into just two builds - the speeder bike and the tree.  I did have some trouble, however, discerning between the lighter and darker shades of brown so I would recommend a well-lit build space.  The blending of browns and the viewpoint used in the instructions also made it a little difficult to see exactly where to place some pieces.

Parts

Nothing to get excited about here, really.  As I only build the Star Wars models now, it was nice to see some foliage again.  There are about three small Technic's parts for the catapult which I wish they could have avoided (and I also think look out of place on the final model).

Minifigures

I actually found the Ewoks to be surprisingly well detailed.

Logray's headpiece is excellent, with sculpted skull and tassels.  He also has a sculpted shoulder bag which was a nice touch.  I wish they could have done something about creating a real (more movie-accurate) staff for him, rather than using the standard spear but it's a small point.

Tokkat's headpiece is also detailed but with the details printed on rather than sculpted.  A small point to mention, and probably not important to most, is that he is not movie-accurate.  Tokkat originally had dark brown fur, with a lighter brown nose and hands whereas this figure is mostly black.

And finally, the scout trooper.  It is strange that the minifigure I wanted most is perhaps the most disappointing.  This is essentially the same figure they have been producing since the 1999 set 'Speeder Bikes' (7128), albeit with a different head (that you will never see).  Standing next to the detailed stormtroopers, snowtroopers and new Imperial pilots, this minifigure just looks bare.  No printing on the helmet and no back print.  I was also not happy with his blaster as he should have had a smaller pistol (like the ones you get with the clone commanders).  He really needs an update.

The build

I actually enjoyed the build but it was quite easy and just took an hour (in front of the TV).

The speeder bike was simple and should be familiar to anyone who has built one since 2009.

The tree was actually quite engaging - straightforward, but it was nice to see it shape-up.  I made a few minor placement errors due to misreading the instructions (see above for the reasons) but they were easily spotted and quick to alter.

The completed model

The speeder bike is excellent, as I knew it would having built similar ones before.  I actually like the extended plate at the back as it lets you place another figure there (re-creating some scenes from the movie) and still have some detail on the rear.

To me the tree also looks quite good.  It looks like a tree that has been altered to ambush people.  The traps, for the most part, work well and I felt there was plenty of room to place the Ewok minifigures.  I was particularly impressed with the falling-log trap and had great fun knocking my stormtroopers over with it.  The sliding log also works a treat for smashing Imperials right in the head.

There were some concerns:

The flick-fire missile (as most people have mentioned) is useless as a missile.  It does make a nice decorative branch, however.

The catapult was the opposite, with the small bricks flying for miles (and nearly getting lost).

I personally cannot fit Tokkat in the hiding space holding his bow and arrow (as it shows on the box).  I have to remove the bow and hang it on the flick-fire missile (see - another use for it) before I can fully close the compartment.

Summary

Overall, this set would definitely appeal to anyone who wants to play with it.  I was amazed with the amount of playable gimmicks it has for a smaller model.  It also includes just enough minifigures to let it standalone. 

At the end of the day, though, the main model is just a tree.  There is nothing about it that says 'Star Wars' and it could easily have come from one of the 'Castle' sets I used to play with back in the Eighties.  I feel this might be a major problem for some people - particularly those who want to place it on a shelf.

That said, the speeder and the minifigures may persuade you otherwise.

author: tkettle9719
title: Attack of the Teddy Bears!
review:
I got this set at regular price at the Lego Store nearest me, and must say that I'm impressed at how playable this set actually is.

Pros

  • The tree has about five different play features, and the minifigures are all new and varied to my collection.
  • The speeder bike is a must-have for collectors, as it is an amazing new rendition. 

Cons

  • The Missile on the base looks very awkward in the set.
  • The ladder is there for a point, but also looks weird on this set since it isn't brown.

This set is really a minifigure pack for most people, but to me it's something more, and I appreciate Lego making this. Buy one for yourself, or a couple for an epic battle.

author: Chills
title: Small set, lots of fun
review:
I picked up this set while ordering some other sets to get free shipping, and I'm really glad I did. While it is a small set LEGO has packed a lot of cool little features in it.


Pros

  • Pro 1 - Pieces. Many SW sets have a lot of the same pieces, so you can build multiple wings, cannons, etc. But this one has so many unique pieces, especially for a small set. 
  • Pro 2 - Build. The build was a lot of fun. Very few X2 steps. 
  • Pro 3 - Minifigures. One reason I got this was for the Ewoks, and I wasn't disappointed. LEGO put a lot of detail into them. I can't wait to get more Endor sets and expand my collection.
  • Pro 4 - Playability. For such a small set there's a lot in it from the movies. There's a little catapult and logs that roll down. It's got a flick-missle and even a section that opens up so you can put one of the Ewoks inside the "tree." I really dig the speeder bike design. 

Cons

  • Con 1 - I would have liked to have one more speeder bike and/or another Imperial trooper.
  • Con 2 - Price. It's not too expensive for what you get, but for the number of pieces I think the set should be prices a few dollars lower.

This is my first Endor set, so I can't compare it to others, but I think it is really well done. You can tell quite a bit of thought went into it to make it fun, reflect scenes from ROTJ, yet the price isn't terrible.

author: tvih
title: Seems overpriced, but still fun!
review:
Just picked this set up today at a local market at a steep discount - got lucky and paid a mere 10 euros for it! Which is all well and good, because despite being a fun little set, at normal price this set feels overpriced and I never would've picked it up.

Box/Instructions

The box is typical - oversized, and with depictions of the contents and functionality of the set, and lists a couple of other Star Wars sets.

I was surprised to find that the instructions had no less than 50 pages. That felt like a lot for just 166 pieces that this set has, but in the end the building pace and amount of steps was good. The instructions were clear enough, as usual, though in dimmer lighting I had some problems a few times making a distinction between the various installed parts in the instructions since they were mostly brown.

Parts

There's a fair amount of parts for such a small set. Also a decent amount of special bricks, most notably for the speeder thingie, and of course the ewoks. As mentioned, most parts are brown, with some green, black and gray thrown into the mix.

Minifigures

Three minifigs are included - two ewoks, Tokkat and Logray, and the Imperial scout trooper. As with other figures with short legs, the ewoks have the unfortunate downside of limited "posability" - you can't move the legs. Combine this with an unmovable head, and the only thing you CAN move on the ewoks are the arms and hands.

The Imperial Trooper is nicely enough made. But I do wish they would've added an additional normal stormtrooper as well, especially given the normal retail price of the set and the fact that the speeder can hold two minifigs.

The build

The build was easy and uncomplicated, as mentioned above about the instructions. It's really best to have some free space for building the set though, as the bags aren't numbered and different parts for the same stage of the build can all come from different bags, so it's easiest if you can spread them all for an easier time finding the correct parts.

The completed model

The speeder bike is nice, even if nothing entirely new or spectacular (except for me in the sense that it was my first). The "tree hideout" of the ewoks is a bit cramped, especially the interior, but has a nice set of traps for the poor scout - an extensible plank, a falling log trap, a flick-fire spear (or whatever it is) and even a small catapult. So, that's plenty for a set this small, and good for playability, although the catapult and flick-fire spear can be a bit tricky to use.

Summary

Overall a nice set, but overpriced at regular retail price.

author: Marorsharpe
title: An fun build that is marred by the price
review:
This kit first off is very nicely done, I enjoyed constructing it due to the fact that there is very little repetition, which can be frustrating and spoil the fun. Lots of nice little play features for you to enjoy. 

Pros

  • The Ewok's and scout trooper are great little mini figures!
  • Lots of projectiles 
  • A fun build that isn't repetitive

Cons

  • The biggest issue is its cost. If you can get it on a deal, do.
  • It's a shame the smaller mini figures lack some pose ability 

All in all a good set, worth getting for the speeder bike! It's very nice. Just expensive

author: wii1232
title: Lots of Secret Weapons!
review:
This set is awesome.  The two best parts are the two new ewoks and all of the secret weapons that they are ready to release upon the Scout Trooper:

The secret compartment, the flick-fire missile, the logs, the big sliding branch, and the catapult with the stones!

author: alfred_the_buttler
title: A great addition to your Endor collection
review:
So I recently purchased 10236 Ewok Village and decided that I needed to get the rest of the Endor sets. There aren't too many Endor sets out there and they all date back to shortly before the village was released. 8038 Battle for Endor is the oldest of these sets and this set is a perfect compliment to that set as it contains a crucial play feature. Where Battle for Endor gave you a AT-ST, it didn't really give you anything to attack it with, aside from a hang glider that drops rocks. The Ewok Village gave us logs that smash either side of it, but this set gives you logs that can be rolled in front of it to trip it up. It's a strange play feature to include in a set that only has a speeder bike as it requires an AT-ST to be put to use, but it is an important part of the Battle for Endor. Now onto the review. 

Minifigures

So you get a biker scout to ride the speeder bike, and there is no question that he is an important minifigure to include in this set. However, it is the Ewoks that make this set exciting. 

Logray is also included in the Ewok Village but he was first introduced in this set and looks fantastic with his satchel. Of course having duplicate Ewok minifigures isn't a huge problem as you will probably want to get many of them to build up your army. 

Tokkat on the other hand is unique to this set, so if you are trying to complete your Ewok collection this set is crucial. The minifigure looks fantastic as the dark green hood really compliments his dark fur quite nicely. 

The Speeder Bike

The speeder bike is slightly different from the ones that appear in the other Endor sets, however the overall design remains unchanged. Even though I have three different designs between this set, Battle for Endor, and 9489 Battle Pack, they are all similar enough that they look fine together. Of the three designs I think that this one happens to be my favorite and therefore I pieced together two additional ones on Bricklink. The newest iteration in 75238 Action Battle eliminated the unique bike mold so it doesn't fit in well with these designs, that one is also my son's so I don't have it with my Endor collection. 

The Tree

This is the main build for this set and is a very interesting build for a Star Wars set as trees are typically not something you see too often. That said, it is very small and certainly out of scale when compared to Battle for Endor or Ewok Village. That said it's girth isn't too much of a problem, but it's height is. I suppose you could argue the Ewoks cut down this tree to construct a fortification. Like most vegetation builds, it is pretty random but is really nothing more than simple stacking. Probably the best thing about it is it has plenty of plant bricks, and they come in two shades of green. 

The tree also has a handful of play features. The most important and best feature is the rolling logs. There is a lever on the top that when opened releases two logs and it works great. My only complaint is that there is nothing designed to hold the logs in place on either side of them, only the lever on the top. As a result if you pick up the set, there is a very good chance you will drop the logs thru either side. 

Another play feature is that a quarter of the tree opens up to reveal a hiding place for an Ewok. Nothing too exciting, but not a bad idea as the Ewoks did hide. You get a small catapult that isn't anything special. You also get a sliding I don't know what and I don't know why. All I can figure out is that it lifts the ladder off the ground a bit so that a short Ewok may have trouble climbing it, but a stormtrooper won't even notice it's off the ground. 

Overall

The set isn't perfect, but it also isn't bad. The most important reason to get it is for Tokkat, but also the rolling logs are important as well. If you can find it cheap I highly recommend it. However, its original price is absurdly high for how small a set it is, and now it can be difficult not to have to pay a premium for it on the second hand market. Then again, there are only 4 sets from this time period depicting Endor, so if you've already spent the big bucks on the Ewok Village and Battle for Endor, dropping a few more bucks on this set isn't all that big of a deal. Think of it as a way to build up your Ewok army and get another speeder bike.
